This is a policy that has the support of everyone from patients to transplant surgeons, and it is something that the kidney community has coalesced behind for years.
H.R. 5534 directly addresses that problem by extending Medicare coverage of immunosuppressive drugs past 36 months for patients that do not obtain health care coverage elsewhere.

Unfortunately, that investment is lost and the patient‚Äôs health deteriorates if they cannot get their immunosuppressive drugs and they reject their kidney transplant. We should protect that investment.

A kidney transplant is an investment into the patient‚Äôs future. Medicare pays for the patient‚Äôs kidney transplant if they have the ESRD benefit, but doesn't cover the patient's immunosuppressive drugs past 36 months.

The bill discussed yesterday in @HouseCommerce Health Subcmtee seeks to override and dismiss the viability standard set by the Supreme Court in the wake of medical advances that are saving babies' lives.
As the viability of a baby occurs earlier with the help of medical innovation, the Roe v. Wade standard inherently extends the rights of states to regulate earlier in a pregnancy term.
As an OB/GYN it is incredible to see the medical advances saving the lives of mothers and babies.
The survival of a baby born this early in pregnancy was unheard of, in 1973, but outcomes have improved as medical care has advanced.
In Roe v. Wade, Justice Blackmuns‚Äô opinion states that viability is usually placed at about seven months ‚Äì or 28 weeks ‚Äì but may occur earlier, even at 24 weeks.
The Supreme Court established the viability test in Roe v. Wade in 1973. This standard says that once a baby reaches the point of ‚Äúviability,‚Äù a state may regulate or prohibit abortions
